titleStmt.title: Barry Mann and James Mann to Thomas E. Bramlette
CWG6907

availability.p: This image and transcription is publicly accessible. The image appears courtesy of the repository named in the Source Description. The transcription and annotation were undertaken by Kentucky Historical Society staff, volunteers, and interns. If referencing this document title, accession number, and permanent URL.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition
Early Access

msIdentifier.repository: Kentucky Department for Libraries and Archives
msIdentifier.collection: Office of the Governor, Thomas E. Bramlette: Governor's official correspondence file, petitions for pardons, remissions, and respites 1863-1867

body.p: To his Excellency Thos E. Bramlette

Your Excellency's Petitioner Barry Mann respectfully represents that on or about the 1st day of May 1865 Your petitioner unfortunately became involved in a personal altercation in Louisville for which your petitioner was at the June term of the Louisville Police Court arraigned and tried and a fine imposed upon him of one hundred dollars which your petition was replevied and your petitioner represents that he is young man and a poor man that he is learning the carpenter's trade but that he is at present incapacitated by white swelling from earning a livelihood or doing anything to procure money to discharge said fine and your petitioner humbly petitions your Excellency to exercise your clemency in his behalf and that of his security in said replevin bond who is petioner father James Mann who is also a poor man and petition prays your excellency to excuse remit to him and said security and pardon so much of said fine as may not be coming and accruing to the officers of the said court.
We the undersigned respectfully join in the prayer to your Excellency, of the foregoing petition

Byron Bacon
Jack Gray
Turn over
F G Dunnicker
James Harris
Jos Clement Justice of the peace Jeff Co Ky
Saml Matlock
James R W Smith
Geo W. Johnston
A M Stout
H. G. van Leggern
Philip Speed

Louisville Police Ct
vs
James Mann & Barrny Mann
$100,
22 Aug/65
